quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you ever find yourself saying something like, that's not my job, that's probably a thing you should do.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A simple heuristic for when to step outside your role to unblock progress and increase impact.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And people who are willing to just get the work done will move faster. Their products will be more successful and they probably aren't carrying around all that anger and crappy emotion because as a PM, for better or for worse, and maybe this is not how we all want it to be, but you're oftentimes the emotional center of the team and it's your job to keep people motivated, keep people excited, keep them bought into the project, and you just have to keep that optimism going and it's hard work
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Reframes PM effectiveness as emotional leadership plus bias-to-action, not just planning and coordination.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I'll hop on this sales call, I'll implement this with the customer. You just have to do whatever it takes.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Concrete examples of high-leverage PM behavior: directly engaging customers and doing hands-on work to drive outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: why being data-driven is a red flag for product thinking.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive teaser that challenges the conventional wisdom that “data-driven” is always a positive product trait.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Why product content you find online can be dangerous.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Flags a contrarian perspective on blindly applying popular product advice without context.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It helps ensure roadmaps drive revenue by instantly aligning product with your sales and marketing teams to capture upsell opportunities.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Host)
quotes.context: Actionable product strategy principle: explicitly tie roadmaps to revenue by aligning cross-functionally with sales and marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: it automatically identifies feature gaps from your CRM data and your customer conversations, adds them to shareable roadmaps, easily prioritized by revenue impact, and then seamlessly closes the loop with sales reps via targeted notifications when feature gaps are closed.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Host)
quotes.context: A concrete workflow/operating model for turning customer/CRM signals into prioritized roadmap items and closing the feedback loop with sales.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now with Composer, you can automate your trading with a library of over 1,000 strategies that are easy to understand and tweak using an AI assistant and visual editor.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Host)
quotes.context: Specific example plus data point showing how AI + visual tooling can make complex domains accessible and iteratable for non-experts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Composer is the first ever algorithmic trading platform where you don't need any coding experience.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Host)
quotes.context: A counterintuitive positioning claim that challenges the assumption that algorithmic trading requires coding.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With $1 billion in trading volume and over 1 million trades executed Composer already has many big time investors using the platform regularly.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Host)
quotes.context: Credibility-building adoption metrics that quantify traction and real-world usage.

quotes.topic_title: Three traits of the best PMs
quotes.text: And so the best PMs not only can find the one thing to work on, but they can stay with that one thing long enough to actually finish it.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Highlights a practical definition of prioritization as focus plus follow-through, not just choosing what’s next.

quotes.topic_title: Three traits of the best PMs
quotes.text: And so it's so much more than just a moment in time deciding, but it's the ability to stay with it and to make sure that it continues to be the most important thing, that you finish it and actually see that it works and that you can get people to continue to stay excited and engaged in that project.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Reframes prioritization as an ongoing leadership and momentum-building job, not a one-time decision.

quotes.topic_title: Three traits of the best PMs
quotes.text: Because especially when you're in management, couple layers up in management, I'm not going to remember to follow up on that feature, but if a PM comes back to me and says, "Hey, remember we did that thing, here's what happened." I can't tell you how rare that is and how many times as a leader you might have to ask for that and for the people you don't have to ask that of is one of the best things when I'm looking at PMs and it's easy.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, high-leverage behavior—closing the loop on results—that leaders notice and that many PMs neglect.

quotes.topic_title: Three traits of the best PMs
quotes.text: It's not hard to do that, especially if you've set up metric tracking or you know how to pull that information or you have somebody who can help you get that. It's pretty easy to do and it's really high value activity.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Emphasizes a simple, repeatable practice (metric follow-up) as disproportionately valuable for PM effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Three traits of the best PMs
quotes.text: It's your job. No one else is going to do it, because at the end of the day, you're responsible for outcomes and results.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A blunt accountability model for “carrying the water”: PMs must do unglamorous cross-functional work to drive outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: How to build the simplification muscle
quotes.text: when you write something, read it out loud, literally just read the thing you wrote out loud and half the time you'll realize it's way too complicated, it doesn't make sense.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable editing technique to catch complexity and unclear thinking in PM writing.

quotes.topic_title: How to build the simplification muscle
quotes.text: I read it and then I put it down and I say, "What are you trying to say?"
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A practical review method that forces the author to restate the core point and exposes misalignment between intent and the document.

quotes.topic_title: How to build the simplification muscle
quotes.text: "Just say that. Just say that thing. The thing that you said to me in conversation is the thing you should write."
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Memorable guidance to remove performative “document voice” and write with the clarity of spoken problem/solution framing.

quotes.topic_title: How to build the simplification muscle
quotes.text: those people had an insight on the market that you're in that made the company worth founding and they probably know more than you and so you might want to listen to them.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A counterweight to the common PM instinct to dismiss leadership input—use experienced reviewers to simplify and sharpen priorities.

quotes.topic_title: How to build the simplification muscle
quotes.text: Getting to the one thing you should do is extremely difficult and being able and having the gumption to say no to all those other things is really hard, because there's probably at any given time, 10 things you should do, but you can't do 10 things, you'll never be successful if you do that in a number of things. And so you have to pick one.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A crisp prioritization mental model: success requires choosing a single bet and explicitly rejecting the rest.

quotes.topic_title: Writing tactics and peer feedback loops
quotes.text: The Minto principle is something that I would recommend everyone do, which is put the headline, the full conclusion first and then you're supporting argument second.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A concrete writing framework for making PM communication clearer by leading with the conclusion before details.

quotes.topic_title: Writing tactics and peer feedback loops
quotes.text: A lot of new PMs fall into the trap of thinking that they should have some sort of buildup. Don't do that. Just tell me whatever the thing is, everyone will thank you.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to remove narrative buildup and get straight to the point to respect readers’ time.

quotes.topic_title: Writing tactics and peer feedback loops
quotes.text: I would generally say a rule of thumb would be pretty much every doc you write, you can delete the first two paragraphs that you've written. You don't need them.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for tightening strategy docs and written updates by cutting common throat-clearing.

quotes.topic_title: Writing tactics and peer feedback loops
quotes.text: I have a little Slack workspace that has three people in it, me and two other women who are product leaders, and we oftentimes send each other our work still and we say, "Hey, I'm struggling with this. Can you read it? Help me make it simpler. Can you help me fix this up?"
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A specific example of a lightweight peer feedback loop to edit writing and pressure-test thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Writing tactics and peer feedback loops
quotes.text: I've just found that in order to be good at your job continuously, you need people who can help give you feedback, and the more senior you get, the harder that is.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Highlights why intentionally building a trusted peer group becomes increasingly important as formal feedback decreases with seniority.

quotes.topic_title: Following up on results to learn and advance
quotes.text: if you're launching a product, usually you release something and you have that initial push of a couple of weeks where you're finding bugs and you're maybe you're pulling metrics and everyone remembers it, then I would remember two weeks after that, a month after that, six months after that, put a reminder in your calendar to check your dashboard or check the metrics or check whatever it is that you were doing, and you won't forget and then share them with whoever might care about it.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable post-launch cadence (2 weeks / 1 month / 6 months) for checking outcomes and sharing learnings.

quotes.topic_title: Following up on results to learn and advance
quotes.text: I'm not going to pretend like if you're just great at your job quietly that you're going to get what you want.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that impact alone isn’t enough—visibility and communication matter for career progression.

quotes.topic_title: Following up on results to learn and advance
quotes.text: Great managers are few and far between, and I am of the opinion that I never wanted to rely on someone else to get what I wanted.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A career ownership mindset: don’t depend on managerial excellence to ensure your work is recognized.

quotes.topic_title: Following up on results to learn and advance
quotes.text: I would always make sure to share that, always make sure to share my progress because I didn't want to leave it up to chance that someone would notice.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to proactively broadcast progress/results so outcomes don’t get lost or forgotten.

quotes.topic_title: Following up on results to learn and advance
quotes.text: The more you ship, the more you learn. And that's why it can take years to build up expertise because you just have to ship a lot of stuff.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A learning model for PM growth: expertise compounds through repeated shipping and feedback loops over time.

quotes.topic_title: How long it takes to get good
quotes.text: And so then two more years. So, that's five years until I really felt like I knew what I was doing. And that's because it takes a long time to ship stuff.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Sets a realistic timeline for PM mastery and ties confidence to the inherently long feedback loops of shipping.

quotes.topic_title: How long it takes to get good
quotes.text: But to me staying at that, when I was at Drip, I was there for almost four years. I got to see two or three cycles of the same product and I learned more from that than I did out of the year or so I spent doing other things each at a time because you got to see the consequences of your decisions and that's rare.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Argues for depth over breadth: repeated product cycles create rare cause-and-effect learning that accelerates growth.

quotes.topic_title: How long it takes to get good
quotes.text: for better or for worse, spending the time is really helpful and I think allowed me to move faster later because I had just spent the time grinding it out for a while in order to be better later.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career strategy: slower early progression can compound into faster advancement later through accumulated judgment.

quotes.topic_title: How long it takes to get good
quotes.text: There are lots of really good reasons to bounce. I've done it, many people have done it, but I was surprised at how much I value that experience of having stuck around for a while and how much I learned from it was something I hadn't expected going into it
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Balances job-hopping with an unexpected upside of staying: deeper learning than anticipated from longer tenure.

quotes.topic_title: How long it takes to get good
quotes.text: and my answer is always create impact and that can take time.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A simple promotion heuristic: focus on impact, acknowledging it often requires patience and longer cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Carrying the water and doing unglamorous work
quotes.text: If you ever find yourself saying something like, that's not my job, that's probably a thing you should do.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A simple rule-of-thumb for PM ownership: treat anything blocking outcomes as yours to handle.

quotes.topic_title: Carrying the water and doing unglamorous work
quotes.text: as a PM for better or for worse, and maybe this is not how we all want it to be, but you're oftentimes the emotional center of the team and it's your job to keep people motivated, keep people excited, keep them bought into the project, and you just have to keep that optimism going.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Reframes PM work as emotional leadership—maintaining momentum and morale is part of the job.

quotes.topic_title: Carrying the water and doing unglamorous work
quotes.text: Your job isn't just to pick the problem. Your job is to deliver a business result.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A crisp definition of PM accountability that shifts focus from artifacts to outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Carrying the water and doing unglamorous work
quotes.text: And so you're uniquely positioned to have to fill in all the gaps because no one else is incentivized to do that.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Explains why PMs end up doing “unglamorous” work: incentives make gaps otherwise persist.

quotes.topic_title: Carrying the water and doing unglamorous work
quotes.text: You should QA your products. That's great if you have a QA team, you should QA them. You should know how they work. You should implement with your customers, you should be able to sell them, you should be able to find users. All that stuff is stuff that you should be able to do, and none of it is above you.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of “carry the water” behaviors PMs can adopt immediately to unblock shipping and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: So, the most common two paths that I've seen are people who switched laterally within a company. Again, challenging but can be done. Or people who joined startups.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Highlights two practical, repeatable entry routes into PM when formal entry-level programs are scarce.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: The reason why people don't do it is because as a manager, it takes a lot of work because there's so much that these people need to learn.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Explains the hidden hiring-manager cost behind why career-switchers struggle to get their first PM role.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: And what we ended up doing is she and I spent four months working together in a WeWork in person to help her onboard really quickly into the role, which was so rewarding.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of the intensive onboarding investment sometimes required to successfully ramp a first-time PM.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: if you can get someone to stamp you with the product manager role, take it.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: Actionable career advice: prioritize getting the PM title because it unlocks future opportunities via resume screening.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management
quotes.text: So, it's like, have you been at PM before? What have you shipped?
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A simple screening rubric/mental model for PM hiring that candidates can prepare for explicitly.

quotes.topic_title: A tactical template for writing product strategy
quotes.text: What is the mission? What is the point of the company? What are our goals? Maybe we have some sort of high level framing of what we're working on. And then I had this big section that was just the landscape. And in that section I put in what's going on with our business? What's happening with our products? What's our point of view on the market? Who are our competitors? A SWOT analysis, key risks that we might be facing. Just dump that all on paper.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable structure for starting a strategy doc that forces clarity on mission/goals and a comprehensive landscape scan.

quotes.topic_title: A tactical template for writing product strategy
quotes.text: Then I wanted to understand where are we. So what is an honest accounting of the current state of your product, the business overall, and then the specific area that you're working in. What works, what doesn't work? What are your customers saying? Bottoms up feedback, users, customers, teams, what are your support tickets? Get that all out on paper. And then really importantly, where are your technical hurdles? What are the big pieces of tech debt? What are your engineering and technical teams always harping on that they want to invest in? Are there some big things coming down the pipe that you need to think about? Just get everything on paper.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A tactical checklist for grounding strategy in reality: customer signals plus technical constraints and debt, documented explicitly.

quotes.topic_title: A tactical template for writing product strategy
quotes.text: From all of that, what's going to bubble up as the top one or two opportunities for your team? Where do you want to play? Where can you win? Where's the unique? Based on your unique competitive advantage, where do you think you all should be and why?
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A focused opportunity-selection lens that narrows strategy to 1–2 bets using “where to play / where to win” and differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: A tactical template for writing product strategy
quotes.text: And you should be able to walk all the way from your company's mission down to the individual priority on your team and see the logic chain and why you got there. And if anyone doesn't agree with it, they can call out where their disagreement lands in that landscape. But at least then you've put everything on paper, you understand how you got to where you're going, and then you can have an argument about the different pieces and points of data and feedback that you're getting, but at least people understand how you got where you got. And then it doesn't become like, I don't agree with you. It becomes, I don't agree with this point.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A method for alignment and productive conflict: make the logic chain explicit so disagreements target assumptions/data, not people.

quotes.topic_title: A tactical template for writing product strategy
quotes.text: I don't think every product needs a strategy. Every feature doesn't need a strategy for example, you don't need to do this if you're working on a tiny slice of a product and you have user feedback, don't overcomplicate it, just do the stuff that makes sense.
quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.context: A counterweight to over-strategizing: reserve heavy strategy work for higher-level, longer-horizon bets; keep small work simple.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core practice for both growth and feature evaluation, reinforcing it as a must-have capability for product teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I left most was our experimentation platform where I could set up experiments, easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of the leverage from self-serve experimentation—speeding iteration by reducing dependency on others for setup and analysis.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance and out of the box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable emphasis on using better stats + tooling to shorten experiment duration and reduce analysis bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel,
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces the “A/B testing flywheel” mental model—sharing insights compounds learning and generates new experiment ideas.
